From: Jim Dixon <jdd@...>
> However, you should NEVER put an assertion in setUp().  JUnit runs setUp()
> before each of your test methods, the ones whose name begins with "test".
> It is intended for use in setting up test fixtures, the set of objects
> that the tests are run against.

Is that a compelling argument for "never" putting an assertion in setUp?
It's
probably not somethiing you want to do often, but...

The setUp method is indeed intended for setting up test fixtures. It's a
place
for putting common test set-up code, per Test Infected: "It would be nice to
reuse some of this test set-up code. In other words, we would like to have a
common fixture for running the tests."

My example: All tests in the TestCase create a common file. Before running
the test, you want to ensure the file is gone, otherwise your tests are
potentially
invalid. So my setup includes: assertTrue(new File("x").delete());. I could
put
(a method call to) the assertion at the start of each test method, but setUp
provides a more succinct way of eliminating this duplication.

Is there a better way of doing this?

The way I look at it is that setUp and tearDown execute as part of each
test,
not before and after the tests.

Jeff L.
